newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan dollar ends down, hitting T$27.50 support.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan dollar ends down, hitting T$27.50 support.

text.p: The Taiwan dollar closed slightly lower against the U.S. dollar on Monday, once breaking what recently had been strong support at T$27.50 on unexpected and active outflows of foreign funds, dealers said.
The local currency ended at T$27.500 to the U.S. dollar against Saturday's T$27.493 close, off a low of T$27.510.
Turnover was an active US$226.5 million.
The Taiwan dollar opened lower to reflect the U.S. dollar's strength overseas, dealers said.
"Then, in morning trading, one foreign bank suddenly bought a lot U.S. dollars for expatriation, pushing the Taiwan dollar down a level not seen since early September," said one dealer.
"Once the market saw the local dollar break its T$27.50 support, U.S. dollar buying strengthened immediately," he said.
This in turn triggered active entry by local banks who offered U.S. dollars to smooth the Taiwan dollar's depreciation, dealers said.
"We saw no apparent entry by the central bank, but seeing several local banks making such a concordant move still might indicate the central bank's influence," another dealer said.
Dealers also noted high interest by exporters to sell U.S. dollars once the Taiwan dollar fell below T$27.50.
A T$27.495-27.510 range was seen for Tuesday.
